summary: the nomenclature and taxonomy of CoVs have been revised by the Coronavirus Study Group of the international committee for taxonomy of Viruses. they are now classified into three genera, Alphacoronavirus, Betacoronavirus, and Gammacoronavirus, replacing the three traditional groups. novel CoVs, which represented a novel genus, Deltacoronavirus, have also been identified (4, 5) a total of 49 laboratory-confirmed cases of MERS-CoV infection have been reported with 27 deaths (36), giving a crude fatality rate of 55%. a macaque model for MERS-CoV infection has also been established which showed that the virus caused localized-to-widespread pneumonia in all infected animals. the source of this novel CoV is still obscure, which has hindered public health and infection control strategies. mammalian cell lines, including primate, porcine, bat, and rabbit cells, may be explained by the use of the evolutionarily conserved dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) as its functional receptor (46, 47) these results suggested that MERS-CoV may possess broad species tropism and may have emerged from animals. studies on genetic diversity and evolution of lineage C betaCoVs in bats would be important. RNA was extracted from the respiratory and alimentary specimens using a QIAamp viral RNA Mini Kit (QIAgen, Hilden, Germany) the RNA was eluted in 50 l of AVE buffer (QIAgen) and was used as the template for reverse transcription-PCR. the PCR products were gel purified using a QIAquick gel extraction kit (QIAgen, Hilden, Germany) both strands of the PCR products were sequenced twice with an ABI Prism 3700 DNA Analyzer. sequences of the PCR products were compared with known sequences of the RdRp genes of CoVs in the GenBank database to identify lineage C betaCoVs. the heptad repeat regions were predicted by using the coiled-coil prediction program MultiCoil2 (55). the heptad repeat regions were predicted by using the coiled-coil prediction program MultiCoil2 (55) TGCAATAAAA-3′ LPW3899 5′-TCTCTTACTAATACATCGGCT-3′ LPW3900 5′-AAGACCTGACCATCTTCAGAAA-3′ LPW3712 5′-CTAGCGCTATAACTTCTAAAAGTA-3′ LPW3712 5′-CTAGCGCTATAACTTCTAAAAGTA-3′ LPW3720 5′-CTAGCGCTATAACTTCTAAAAGTA-3′ AATTGTGTGAACTGTACTGAT-3′ LPW3387 5′-ATATATCTCGAAGTAACGATCAA-3′ LPW3172 5′-GTCCTCTGGCAACTTAATAAAGATT-3′ LPW3130 5′-CTAATATGAGAGAGAGAGAGAGAGAGAGA-3′ LPW1507 5′-GGTTGGGACTATCCTAAGTAAGATT-3′ LPW1508 5′-CCATCAT the number of synonymous substitutions per synonymous site, Ks, and the number of nonsynonymous substitutions per nonsynonymous site, Ka, were calculated using the Nei-Gojobori (Jukes-Cantor) method. positive selection for a site was considered statistically significant if the P value was 0.1 for the SLAC and FEL methods or the posterior probability was at the 90% level for the REL method. dRp sequence data of lineage C betaCoVs from European bats. one parametric model (Constant Size) and one nonparametric model (Bayesian Skyline with five groups) tree prior were used for the inference. analysis was performed using a relaxed clock model with Uced. Viral RNA was extracted from the respiratory and alimentary specimens using a QIAamp viral RNA Mini Kit (QIAgen, Hilden, Germany) the RNA was eluted in 50 l of AVE buffer (QIAgen) and was used as the template for reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR) the mixtures were amplified in 60 cycles of 94°C for 1 min, 48°C for 1 min, and 72°C for 1 min. standard precautions were taken to avoid PCR contamination. sequences of the PCR products were compared with known sequences of the RdRp genes of CoVs in the GenBank database to identify lineage C betaCoVs. PCR products were assembled manually to produce the complete RdRp, S, and N gene sequences. phylogenetic trees were constructed using the maximum-likelihood method (51), with bootstrap values calculated from 100 trees. prediction of transmembrane domains was performed using coiled-coil prediction program MultiCoil2 (55). LPW1040 5′-KYDBWRTTRTARCAMACAAC-3′ LPW3235 5′-CTTAATAAACACTTTTCTATGATGAT-3′ LPW2678 5′-TACTCACCGAGCTGTACTTTACTA-3′ S LPW3797 5′-AGATTTATATAAAATTATGGGAA-3′ LPW4102 5′-TACGTGGTTTTAATAATAAAA-3′ LPW3899 5 LPW3350 5′-TTTGTCAATTTTGGATAGGACAT-3′ LPW3352 5′-TGATGCATCACAGCARCCATA-3′ LPW3351 5′-ATCAGAATAACTGTGAAGTGCTT-3′ LPW3275 5′-GACAATTGGACCAAAAGACGTT-3′ LPW3382 5′-CAAATTGTGTGAACTGTACTGAT-3′ LPW3387 5′-ATATA the number of synonymous substitutions per synonymous site, Ks, and the number of nonsynonymous substitutions per nonsynonymous site, Ka, for each coding region were calculated using the Nei-Gojobori (Jukes-Cantor) method. positive selection for a site was considered statistically significant if the P value was 0.1 for the SLAC and FEL methods or the posterior probability was at the 90% level for the REL method. divergence time was calculated using complete RdRp and N gene sequence data of Ty-BatCoV HKU4, Pi-BatCoV HKU5, and MERS-CoV strains. one parametric model (Constant Size) and one nonparametric model (Bayesian Skyline with five groups) prior were used for the inference. the nucleotide sequences of the complete RdRp, S, and N genes of Ty-BatCoV HKU4 and Pi-BatCoV HKU5 have been lodged in the GenBank sequence database under accession no. KC522036 to KC522119. RT-PCR for a 440-bp fragment in the RdRp genes of CoVs detected the presence of lineage C betaCoVs from two bat species. SS, predicted signal peptide; RBD, receptor binding domain; HR1, heptad repeat 1; HR2, heptad repeat 2; TM, transmembrane domain. the tMRCA of MERS-CoV, Ty-BatCoV HKU4 and Pi-BatCoV HKU5 was estimated at 1520.09 (HPDs, 745.73 to 1956.12) the tMRCA of MERS-CoV, Ty-BatCoV HKU4 and Pi-BatCoV HKU5 was estimated at 1323.51 (HPDs, 383.58 to 1897.75) a total of 5,426 respiratory and 5,260 alimentary specimens from 5,481 bats were obtained. RT-PCR for a 440-bp fragment in the RdRp genes of CoVs detected the presence of lineage C betaCoVs from two bat species. none of the respiratory samples were positive for lineage C betaCoVs. Phylogenetic analysis of the complete RdRp, S, and N gene sequences of Ty-BatCoV HKU4 and Pi-BatCoV HKU5 showed that the sequences from the 13 Ty-BatCoV HKU4 strains and 15 Pi-BatCoV HKU5 strains formed two distinct clusters in all three genes, being closely related to each other and to MERS-CoV. wise amino acid identity (%) Ty-BatCoV HKU4_2 Pi-BatCoV HKU5_31 MERS-CoV RdRp S N RdRp S N RdRp S encoded 1,350 to 1,352 and 1352 to 1,359 aa. a potential cleavage site, though not perfectly conserved, could be present in the S proteins of Ty-BatCoV HKU4 and Pi-BatCoV HKU5. two heptad repeats (HR), important for membrane fusion and viral entry (61), were located at residues 978/980 to 1124/1126 (HR1) and 1251/1253 to 1285/1287 (HR2) for Ty-BatCoV HKU4 and residues 978/979/983/984 to 1124/1125/1129/1130 (HR1) and 1253/1254/1258/1259 to 1287/1288/1292/1293 (HR2) for Pi-B the receptor for mouse hepatitis virus (66–70) is the receptor for mouse hepatitis virus (66–70) the S proteins of Ty-BatCoV HKU4 and Pi-BatCoV HKU5 as well as MERS-CoV did not exhibit significant sequence homology to the known receptor binding domains. dRp, S, and N genes among different strains of Ty-BatCoV HKU4 and Pi-BatCoV HKU5 were determined. the ratios were generally low, although the S genes of both viruses showed relatively higher ratios (0.118) than the RdRp and N genes. this suggests that these genes were under purifying selection. the figure was generated using WebLogo (91). Detection of positive selection in S genes. the S genes of Pi-BatCoV HKU5 possessed more positively selected sites than the S genes of Ty-BatCoV HKU4. the tMRCA of MERS-CoV, Ty-BatCoV HKU4 and Pi-BatCoV HKU5 was estimated at 1520.09 (HPDs, 745.73 to 1956.12) the tMRCA of MERS-CoV and three European bat CoV strains was estimated at 1859.32 (HPDs, 1636.67 to 1987.55) DISCUSSION In this study, Ty-BatCoV HKU4 and Pi-BatCoV HKU5 were found to be highly prevalent among lesser bamboo bat and Japanese pipistrelle in Hong Kong. the genetic distance between MERS-CoV and the various strains of MERS-CoV was still large, with their S proteins having 67.4% aa identity. nsp14 sequence shared 85.7% nucleotide and 95.5% amino acid identity with that of MERS-CoV (45) compared to 81.9% and 83.4% to 84.2% nucleotide and 88.6% and 92% amino acid identity differences between Ty-BatCoV and Pi-BatCoV. the divergent sequences of the S genes of Pi-BatCoV HKU5 may suggest that the virus has a better ability to generate variants to occupy new ecological niches. the divergent sequences of the S genes of Pi-BatCoV HKU5 may suggest that the virus has a better ability to generate variants. a much higher number of positively selected sites were observed in the S gene of Pi-BatCoV HKU5 than in that of Ty-BatCoV HKU4. this suggests that the S1 region of Pi-BatCoV HKU5 may have been under functional constraints in its host species, Japanese pipistrelle. partial sequences closely related to those of MERS-CoV detected in bats from Europe also originated from Pipstrellus bats (P. pipistrellus, P. nathusii, and P. pygmaeus) the difference between this BatCoV and MERS-CoV within the partial nsp14 sequence was also found to be mainly due to substitutions in the third nucleotide positions. roost in bamboo stems may reflect lower mutation rate observed in the S gene of Ty-BatCoV HKU4 and Pi-BatCoV HKU5, as well as other lineage C betaCoVs in bats, utilize the same receptor as MERS-CoV. this suggests these betaCoVs belonging to lineage C may utilize a receptor(s) different from those of other CoVs. bats harbor diverse CoVs, which is likely the result of their species diversity, roosting behavior, and migrating ability (16, 18, 29, 31, 32, 89) it remains to be ascertained if bats could also be the animal origin for the emergence of MERS-CoV either directly or via an intermediate host.
